newsitem.title: UK: BADMINTON-CHINA BATTLE PAST INDONESIA, DENMARK FAIL.
newsitem.headline: BADMINTON-CHINA BATTLE PAST INDONESIA, DENMARK FAIL.

text.p: China, the defending champions, clinched a place in the Sudirman Cup mixed team badminton final on Friday, edging home 3-2 against big rivals Indonesia.
With Susi Susanti scoring a surprise win over world champion Ye Zhaoying the outcome eventually rested on the final women's doubles tie.
But, this time, there was never any hint of an upset as the Olympic champions Ge Fei and Gu Jun cruised to a 15-3 15-3 victory over Eliza and Rosiana Zelin.

In the final, China will meet South Korea who took a winning 3-1 lead over Denmark late on Friday. All England champions Kang Kyung-jin and Ha Tae-kwon ended Denmark's hopes of becoming the first European side to reach the final by repeating their All England final victory over Jon Holst-Christensen and Michael Sogaard.

South Korea, who won the cup in 1991 and 1993, foiled a gamble by Danish coach Henrik Lyngby who omitted Olympic champion Poul-Erik Hoyer-Larsen in favour of Peter Rasmussen, a player who has a fine record against Koreans.

But a three game defeat for Rasmussen all but sunk Danish hopes. Rasmussen, the world no 12, took the opening game 15-6 against Park Sung-woo, but the world silver medallist hit back to win the next two games, 15-11 15-4.

Camilla Martin gave Denmark a much-needed win in the singles. The 23 year-old European champion was in great form, winning 11-7 11-0 in under 15 minutes. But Martin's victory just delayed the inevitable. Kang and Ha always held the upper-hand against Holst-Christensen and Sogaard, and ran out 15-11 18-16 winners.
Saturday's final is a repeat of the group one match on Thursday, which China won 3-2, the Koreans only narrowing the gap by taking the two dead rubbers.

In the top group play-off, Sweden relegated England to division two with a surprisingly decisive 4-1 win. Thomas Johansson clinched victory in the third rubber with a fighting 15-7 15-18 15-10 win over former European champion Darren Hall.
In the earlier semi, China gained a swift advantage with Liu Yong and Ge taking the mixed doubles in straight games, 18-15 15-13, against Limpele Flandy and Minarti Timur.

But the ever popular Susanti, one of the most successful ever woman players, set the match alight when she staged a thrilling fightback against Ye. The Chinese player comfortably took the opening game 11-6, but Susanti, the former world champion who has now dropped to number five in the world, sent the tie into a third end by taking the second 11-6.

The decider was totally one-sided with Susanti, who recently married the former Olympic Champion, Allan Budi Kusuma, in totally dominant form, while Ye crumbled dramatically under the pressure and failed to win a point in going down 11-6 6-11 11-0.
It was a win that raised Indonesia's hopes of reclaiming the title that had eluded them since the inaugural year of 1989 in Jakarta and helped set the stage for a dramatic climax.

China regained the advantage in the men's singles with All-England Champion Dong Jiong crushing veteran Ardy Wiranata 15-2 15-8, but Budiarto Sigit and Chandra Wijaya set-up the final tie decider with a 15-8 15-6 win over Liu and Sun Jun in the men's doubles.
"We all played our best, but China are stronger overall and deserved the win," said Susanti. "I was delighted with my own form and it gives me confidence for next week's individual championships."
